Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: The Role of Symbols in Establishing Political Power

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Since the rise of complex societies, political, military, and religious leaders have materialized power through the creation of distinctive insignias. The manufacture of insignias of power, like masks, is an activity developed through complex artisanal processes carried out by highly trained craftsmen. Cross-culturally, masks can be considered as sacred power objects. For example they can be magical accessories through which ancestors are represented, used as symbols of transformation and concealment in initiation ceremonies, and as markers of social rank. This project will focus on Mayan greenstone mosaic masks and attempt to determine whether they were produced by a single or multiple groups or artisans. The former would suggest that production was tightly elite controlled and thus were manipulated as power symbols. It is hypothesized that the masks were used by a supreme leader of a rising center who sought to expand political influence over minor entities in the region and sealed their affiliation through mask gifting.

Past archaeological investigations at 3 archaeological sites in the Central Maya Lowlands revealed seven ancient royal and one sub-royal burials. Many of these artifacts contained in the burials were studied, conserved, and restored, and some have been temporarily exhibited in museums around the world. Nonetheless, other materials remained unstudied, including fragments (tesserae) of greenstone that form disassembled mosaic faces, which are currently stored in the National Museum in Guatemala City. During a preliminary study in 2015, nearly 1000 greenstone tesserae were identified, which could form at least nine masks. Before restoring these artifacts, this research will explore the craft traditions and technology practiced by ancient Maya craftsmen to create these objects. Using microarchaeological approaches, the dissertation student, Juan Carlos Melendez will conduct a study which compares the manufacture traces obtained through experimental archaeology on greenstone with traces recorded on ancient Maya greenstone tesserae. To preserve the original tesserae, selected sectors will be replicated using segments of replicating tape. In collaboration with the Templo Mayor Museum in Mexico City, the segments will be observed using a scanning electron microscope (SEM), allowing magnifications of up to 1000X. At this scale it will be possible to determine manufacturing similarities or differences when compared to the observations made on experiments carried out on greenstone

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through the doctoral dissertation improvement grant provided by the National Science Foundation, I carried out technological analyses of ancient Maya greenstone mosaic masks (GMM) discovered in three archaeological sites located in the Central Maya Lowlands (CML) of Guatemala: Tikal, El Zotz, and El Perú-Waka’ (EPW). Specifically I conducted analyses to identify micro-traces of manufacture recorded on selected tesserae that formed 9 GMM, all recovered from burials (seven royal and one elite*): Tikal (Burial 19, n=1; and Burial 62, n=1) and El Zotz (Burial 9, n=2) that both date to the Early Classic period (A.D. 250-550), while the other GMM come from EPW  (Burial 8, n=1; Burial 37, n=1; *Burial 38, n=1; Burial 39, n=1; Burial 61, n=1) and all date to the Late Classic Period (A.D. 550-800).

Through the identification of micro-traces of manufacture I expected to determine the raw material of the tools used to produce the GMM, which I hypothesized were symbols of power and elements of affiliation used by rulers of hegemonic regimes to persuade the leaders of minor centers to form an alliance with the regimes. Similar or identical micro-traces of manufacture could provide a line of evidence that suggest the GMM were created using the same artisanal procedures, perhaps by specialist artisans attached to hegemonic regimes. On the other hand, differences between the micro-traces of manufacture could suppose that the GMM were potentially created by several craft traditions, probably by independent artisans.

Besides the objects of study that were originally mentioned in my research proposal, I had the opportunity to include another 7 GMM and 2 unique greenstone mosaic vases (GMV) in my research. One of those GMM was discovered in a royal burial at Tintal, which is an ancient settlement located in the CML. Another one was discovered by the University Pennsylvania Museum in the 1960’s inside Burial 160 at Tikal. Moreover, during the preventive conservation processes carried out on the greenstone material found in Burial 8 from EPW, it was determined that at least two more GMM were placed inside the interment, which were also included in this study. Three of four GMM found in the 80’s inside a cache vessel discovered in front of Structure 86 at Tak’alik Ab’aj were also included in this study. Finally, two greenstone mosaic vases discovered in royal burials from Tikal were also included. The first one was discovered in Tomb 196, located inside Structure 5D-73, while the second was found in Tomb 116, which was discovered inside Structure 5D-1. The reason to include these other 9 artifacts (i.e., 7 GMM and 2 GMV) in this study is to expand the comparative reference collection, both among the masks as well as the GMV. In addition, it is a unique opportunity to approach the study of ancient craft production of power objects from a microscopic perspective on a regional level.

Preliminary results suggest that the raw materials of the tools used to manufacture the GMM from Tak’alik Ab’aj (AD 300) were different to those used to manufacture the GMM from Tikal (AD 378), Tintal (AD 300-400), and El Zotz (AD 350-400.) Based on this evidence, it is more probable that the manufacture of “power objects” in the Maya area was regionally developed by different craft traditions (i.e., Central Maya Lowlands vs. Pacific Coast), even though some of the stylistic features of the Tak’alik Ab’aj GMM resemble the one discovered in Burial 62 from Tikal.

The methodology used to identify the micro-traces of manufacture of selected tesserae that form the 16 GMM and the two GMV was carried out through the replication of select sectors of the tesserae using polymers. This latter step was carried out in Guatemala City. The replicated polymers were subsequently analyzed in Mexico City under the project “Estilo y Tecnología de los Objetos Lapidarios del México Antiguo” conducted by Dr. Emiliano Melgar from the “Museo del Templo Mayor.” In Mexico City, the polymers were covered with a metallic coat of gold using a sputter coater “Desk II,” and were subsequently observed using a scanning electron microscope (SEM) “Jeol JSM-6460LV.” The micrographs obtained through the SEM observations are being compared to those taken from experiments that emulate the ancient manufacture of greenstone ornaments. Dr. Adrián Velazquez and Dr. Melgar, both researchers of the Templo Mayor Museum, have applied the replicating methodology for the past 17 years in the study of malacological and lapidary material from Mesoamerica and abroad.

Overall, for this project, I have successfully observed 530 polymers, which have resulted in 2536 micrographs. These micrographs have preliminarily been compared to previous microscopic images that are the result of experiments compiled by the “Experimental Archaeology Lapidary Workshop” of the Templo Mayor Museum. I am currently analyzing and measuring the micro-traces of manufacture recorded on each micrograph to create an essential reference collection.
